text: Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: I mean, I think the rise is so small. We know it is just starting to breakthrough. Family Member: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: But, probably can’t definitively prove it right now on scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the scans are so nonsensitive. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even the PET scan. You know, sensitive but not that sensitive. Patient: Right. Doctor: If it’s just a small amount of cells, but it is enough of a sign for me. If you’re taking a medicine, it is supposed to make your PSA go down, and it starts rising up. That’s probably breaking through. So, we need to pile one more drug on there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all of the trials out in the U.S. are now like that. You’re trucking along with Enza, and uh-oh, it’s not working. We slap another medicine on there to see if we can help it. Family Member: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - um we have not seen cases where that is curative. That is also another type of therapy that delays the progression of the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So so for example, if your primary goal was to delay hormone therapy for as long as possible, like if you really wanted at all cost to avoid hormone therapy - Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the one thing that we could consider would be referring you to a radiation oncologist that specializes in the type of radiation called stereotactic radio therapy, which is a very sort of focused - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - razor-sharp beam of radiation that targets one particular area and doesn’t really cause scattering of the x-rays to other areas. So it spares the normal tissues. Patient: Um Doctor: And we have people at this place that do that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um but I don’t want you to go into that therapy believing that this is also a potentially curative therapy. I think it could definitely cure the tumor in that one lymph node that we can see.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer. text: Family Member: Why are they not approving the chemo? Doctor: I have no clue. They don’t have to give a reason remember? They just say denied so then we’re like we don’t understand and then you play the round robin, you know talk to that person, talk to that person, at some point it’s gonna have to be talk to the Medical Director and I’m gonna be like this ain’t complicated. I would image it has probably a lot to do with you were on a trial and now you’re not and they’re behind right. So we’re moving at real time speed… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And stuff that they have is like always behind so you know there isn’t a – there isn’t a visit right now until right now for us to say well you’re done with that study, you’re now getting Taxotere just like a regular non-study patient and I’m sure they haven’t processes that in their head. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they go everything by notes. So everything for you has been on, on, on – oh we’re now going to get radiation, Patient: Okay. Doctor: so they don’t have a way to read and say that what I’m saying correct. Because if it’s not in a document then it isn’t so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that’s a struggle for us, but I have a feeling that’s what it is. But hey this may be a blessing in disguise. You’ve got the fourth coming up, you might as well just enjoy it. We will reschedule next week. I’ll scream at a bunch of more people because what else do I have to do. Doctor: And then by then hopefully the shot will have worked out. Patient: Okay

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
